awd_titl_txt: Highly Parallel Synthesis of Nanostructures Inside Crystalline Protein Scaffolds
awd_abstract_narration:
A grand challenge in nanomaterials manufacturing is the reliable, scalable and reproducible production of metallic nanostructures. The ability to program the synthesis and position of such nanostructures will enable the development of innovative materials for energy storage, light-harvesting or catalysis. Despite a high degree of interest in controlling the growth and placement of nanoparticles using biological materials as templates, it is currently difficult to control the size, shape and position of the resulting inorganic components. With this award, the research team will use engineered protein crystals, highly ordered assemblies of trillions of monomers, as "molds" to direct and limit the growth patterns of guest nanoparticles. Both the resulting nanostructures and the hybrid crystalline assembly of nanoparticles thereof, have potential useful applications. For example, inorganic structures formed within the solvent channels of protein crystals could result in ultra-high surface area materials for catalysis or battery applications. This research will provide interdisciplinary educational training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students in cutting-edge areas of bionanotechnology, molecular modeling, nanostructure synthesis, as well as nanostructure imaging and analysis. Results from this research will therefore benefit both the U.S. economy and society.

Nanoparticle growth is a nucleation phenomenon, making it technically challenging to grow them with uniform size or low symmetry. The research team will decouple nucleation from growth, using well-established affinity interactions to "plant" seed nanoparticles at specific sites within the protein lattice. Seeded nuclei will then be subjected to controlled growth within the anisotropic protein matrix. The resulting hybrid crystals will be characterized using multiple techniques including x-ray diffraction, elemental analysis, and electron microscopy. Nanoparticles released from the host crystals will likewise be characterized via electron microscopy. In comparison with existing approaches for the template-directed deposition of inorganic structures, crystalline scaffolds will provide a higher degree of order and the unique possibility of high-resolution structure determination.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The unusual properties of nanoparticles can be enhanced in ordered assemblies or by growing nanostructures with new shapes.

Our project, a collaboration between a precise nanocluster synthesis team and a protein crystal engineering group, focused on evaluating the nanomanufacturing capabilities enabled by highly porous, crosslinked protein crystals. Compared to other materials that might serve as nanoparticle organization scaffolds or nanostructure growth molds, crosslinked protein crystals offer potential advantages in terms of stability and precision. Protein crystals also represented a less explored scaffold for organizing metallic nanoparticles in three dimensions.

Our first major milestone was the successful engineering of a highly stable protein crystal containing a honeycomb array of 13 nanometer pores. We also demonstrating the ability to capture or release specially designed gold nanoclusters within the scaffold crystal by changing the solution conditions.

We were able to better understand the process of loading the gold nanoclusters into the crystals by using confocal microscopy and developing a computer model for the diffusion and adsorption processes.

Having successfully met our first aim, the controlled capture of gold “seeds”, we turned to our second aim, determining if the host crystal could serve as a “mold” to delimit the growth of gold nanostructures. We first observed the nanostructure of the empty crystals using electron microscopy and atomic force microscopy.

Finally, we were able to show that protein crystals could indeed serve as a semi-flexible “mold” for nanostructure growth. By demolishing the surrounding protein crystal, we could liberate gold nanorods and gold nanorod bundles connected via delicate, sparse interconnects. We observed these novel nanostructures using electron microscopy.

The major broader impact of this project consisted of the educational training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students in bionanotechnology, molecular modeling, nanostructure synthesis, as well as nanostructure imaging and analysis. In addition to a core team of graduate student researchers, a variety of undergraduates had the opportunity to obtain training via the project. Four undergraduates made contributions sufficient for authorship on previous or pending publications.


Last Modified: 12/18/2017
Modified by: Christopher D Snow

Images (1 of )

    Kowalski et al. in Nanoscale. 2016 Jul 7;8(25):12693-6. doi: 10.1039/c6nr03096c

Representative images of fluorescent Au25(GSH)18 nanoclusters diffusing along the z-axis into an initially non-fluorescent CJ-LPC scaffold over the course of 1 hour; Scale bar:40 ?m
    Luke Hartje in J Phys Chem B. 2017 Aug 17;121(32):7652-7659. doi: 10.1021/acs.jpcb.7b03999
